comments.text:
[Scrum Master] Sprint 1 Retrospective

== WHAT WENT WELL ==

1. Unified kickoff (controls + PDL in single pass) worked smoothly
2. TDD RED->GREEN->REFACTOR produced clean, tested code on first pass
3. Beads tracking gave full audit trail of agent orchestration
4. 67 tests, 0 defects, all ACs met
5. Run-log pattern captured the workflow narrative

== WHAT TO IMPROVE ==

1. FRAMEWORK GAPS FOUND MID-SPRINT
   - Release Notes missing from PDL framework
   - Run evidence not persisted as standard practice
   - bd gate type documented incorrectly in skill file
   Impact: Fixed immediately, but should go through framework backlog
   Action: Raise as framework improvement items, not mid-sprint hotfixes

2. BRANCHING MODEL NOT FOLLOWED
   - All commits on main/master -- no feature branches
   - G1 gate (PR merge) not exercisable without branches
   - SoD for code review not enforceable
   Action: Sprint 2 must use feature branches with PRs

3. BEADS STATE MANAGEMENT
   - Stale workflow labels accumulated (in-review AND governance-review)
   - Stories left in_progress when agent work was complete
   - Sprint closure sequence not modelled until end
   Action: Define clean label transition rules, model closure in workflow

4. FRAMEWORK CONSUMPTION MODEL UNDEFINED
   - Agent files read from local filesystem
   - No version pinning or submodule structure
   - No separation between framework team and consuming team
   Action: Evaluate git submodule (item for framework backlog)

== ACTION ITEMS FOR SPRINT 2 ==

AI-001: Use feature branches per story (Dev Agent)
AI-002: Clean label transitions -- remove old before adding new (all agents)
AI-003: Create run-log at sprint initiation, not retroactively (Scrum Master)
AI-004: Model sprint closure explicitly in workflow (Scrum Master)

== ACTION ITEMS FOR FRAMEWORK BACKLOG ==

FW-001: Release Notes in PDL -- DONE (applied mid-sprint, to be ratified)
FW-002: Run-log pattern -- DONE (applied mid-sprint, to be ratified)
FW-003: Gate type correction in beads skill -- DONE (applied mid-sprint)
FW-004: Evaluate git submodule for framework consumption
FW-005: Define branching model guidance in DEVELOPER.md or framework

[Scrum Master] Sprint 2 Retrospective

== WHAT WENT WELL ==

1. TDD discipline held — all 3 stories followed RED→GREEN→REFACTOR, 39 new tests, 0 defects
2. SQL-first approach produced clean, portable dimension code
3. PII masking reused from Sprint 1 — no reinvention
4. PO actively challenged process gaps — 6 gaps identified and documented honestly
5. Run-log captured gaps in real-time (once created) — better than Sprint 1
6. Feature branches used per story (Sprint 1 retro action AI-001 addressed)

== WHAT TO IMPROVE ==

1. GOVERNANCE KICKOFF SKIPPED
   - No control applicability or PDL Impact Assessment at sprint start
   - Done retroactively — but this means PDL tasks were not tracked during the sprint
   - Action: SM must trigger Governance kickoff before BA starts discovery

2. RUN-LOG CREATED LATE
   - Should have been created before BA discovery (Step 1)
   - Sprint 1 retro action AI-003 not followed
   - Action: SM creates run-log as literal first action of sprint

3. STORY LIFECYCLE GAPS
   - Stories went open→closed without in_progress or --claim
   - No comments during implementation
   - Fixed mid-sprint: DEV-AGENT.md updated with mandatory protocol
   - Action: Enforce in Sprint 3 (Sprint 2 retro action AI-005)

4. BA BOUNDARY VIOLATION
   - BA specified file paths, column names, MERGE patterns in stories
   - PO caught and corrected — stories revised to describe WHAT not HOW
   - Action: BA-AGENT.md should explicitly prohibit technical implementation details (AI-006)

5. CHAINED PR STRUCTURE CAUSED MERGE ISSUES
   - Stacked branches (s004→s005→s006) with chained PRs
   - S005+S006 merged into feature branches, not main
   - Required catch-up PR #4
   - Action: Use single PR per sprint or re-target bases after merge (AI-007)

6. QA AGENT PROVIDES NO INDEPENDENT ASSURANCE
   - QA re-ran Dev tests and mapped to ACs — verification theatre
   - No independent UAT performed
   - C-02 (SoD) partially undermined
   - Action: FW-007 raised — define UAT as distinct from test coordination

7. PDL DOCS UPDATED AFTER GOVERNANCE FLAGGED THEM
   - Architecture and ITOH should have been updated as Dev deliverables during implementation
   - Governance had to flag the gap before Dev updated them
   - PO correction: "we always document what we have done — irrespective of approval"
   - Action: Dev must update architecture + ITOH as part of story implementation, not as G3 remediation (AI-008)

== METRICS ==

Stories: 3/3 delivered (S004, S005, S006)
Tests: 106 total (39 new), 0 defects
TDD: 3/3 verified (RED→GREEN→REFACTOR)
Process gaps identified: 7
Framework items raised: 1 (FW-007 UAT)
Sprint 1 retro actions addressed: 1 of 3 (AI-001 branching — done; AI-002 labels — not tested; AI-003 run-log — failed)

== ACTION ITEMS ==

Sprint-level (for Sprint 3):
  AI-005: Enforce bd --claim and comment logging (DEV-AGENT.md already updated)
  AI-006: Update BA-AGENT.md to prohibit technical implementation details in stories
  AI-007: Use single PR or re-target bases — no stacked branch chains
  AI-008: Dev updates architecture + ITOH during implementation, not post-governance

Framework-level:
  FW-007: Define UAT as distinct activity from QA test coordination (already raised)
  FW-008: Codify "Governance kickoff before BA discovery" as mandatory workflow step

title: S008: Daily Cost Fact Table
description:
## Business Need

The pipeline currently computes a daily cost summary (cost per service per day) but does not persist it. Business users and downstream analytics cannot query historical daily cost data without re-running the entire pipeline.

A persisted daily cost fact table is needed so that:
- Cost analysts can query daily spend by service without re-processing source data
- Trend dashboards can show day-over-day and week-over-week cost movements
- Anomaly detection can reference historical baselines reliably

The fact table must reference the existing service dimension to enable drill-down by service category.

## Acceptance Criteria

AC-1: Daily cost records are persisted in the database, queryable by date and service.
AC-2: Each fact record is linked to the service dimension via a foreign key relationship.
AC-3: Re-running the pipeline for the same date range does not create duplicate records (idempotent).
AC-4: NULL or missing cost values in source data are handled consistently (coalesced to zero with an audit trail).
AC-5: The fact table is loadable from the existing pipeline entry points with no manual steps.
AC-6: All monetary values use consistent precision (two decimal places).
AC-7: A record count per day-service grain is preserved for reconciliation back to source data.

## Controls

- C-06 (Data Quality): NULL handling, type casting, reconciliation counts
- C-07 (Reproducibility): Deterministic output from same inputs
- C-08 (Idempotency): Re-run safety, no duplicate records

## Test Taxonomy

- t1_logic: Aggregation correctness, NULL coalescing, precision
- t2_contract: Schema validation, foreign key integrity to dim_service
- t3_quality: Data quality checks (no NULLs in required fields, valid date ranges)
- t5_idempotency: Re-run produces identical results, no duplicates
- t8_integration: End-to-end load from raw CUR through to queryable fact table

## Dependencies

- Depends on: dim_service (Sprint 2 — delivered)
- Depends on: raw_cur extract layer (Sprint 1 — delivered)

title: S009: Customer Cost Attribution Fact Table
description:
## Business Need

Cost data is currently summarised by service only. The business needs to attribute costs to individual customers so that:
- Finance can report cost-to-serve per customer segment (premium, standard, enterprise)
- Customer success teams can identify high-cost accounts for optimisation outreach
- Margin analysis can compare revenue per customer against their infrastructure cost

The customer cost fact table must join service-level costs with the customer dimension, respecting SCD2 versioning so that historical costs reflect the customer segment that was active at the time.

## Acceptance Criteria

AC-1: Cost records are attributed to customers and persisted in the database, queryable by customer and date.
AC-2: Each fact record is linked to both the customer dimension and the service dimension via foreign key relationships.
AC-3: Customer attribution respects SCD2 versioning — costs are joined to the customer version that was current on the usage date.
AC-4: Re-running the pipeline for the same date range does not create duplicate records (idempotent).
AC-5: NULL or missing cost values are handled consistently (coalesced to zero with an audit trail).
AC-6: The fact table supports aggregation by customer segment for finance reporting.
AC-7: PII controls are maintained — the fact table references customer surrogate keys, never raw PII.

## Controls

- C-04 (PII Masking): No raw PII in fact table; surrogate key references only
- C-06 (Data Quality): NULL handling, type casting, referential integrity
- C-07 (Reproducibility): Deterministic output from same inputs
- C-08 (Idempotency): Re-run safety, no duplicate records

## Test Taxonomy

- t1_logic: Cost attribution correctness, SCD2 temporal join logic, NULL coalescing
- t2_contract: Schema validation, foreign key integrity to dim_customer and dim_service
- t3_quality: Data quality checks (no orphaned foreign keys, no NULLs in required fields, valid date ranges)
- t4_access: PII controls — verify no raw email/phone leaks into fact table
- t5_idempotency: Re-run produces identical results, no duplicates
- t8_integration: End-to-end load from raw CUR and customer snapshots through to queryable fact table

## Dependencies

- Depends on: dim_service (Sprint 2 — delivered)
- Depends on: dim_customer (Sprint 2 — delivered)
- Depends on: raw_cur extract layer (Sprint 1 — delivered)
- Depends on: S008 (Daily Cost Fact Table) — customer costs build on the daily cost grain

comments.text:
PROCESS GAP IDENTIFIED: [PO] QA Agent role lacks independent UAT capability

Current state: QA Agent re-runs Dev's unit tests and maps them to ACs. This is test coordination/reporting, not independent quality assurance.

Gap: No User Acceptance Testing (UAT) exists in the current ASOM workflow. UAT should:
1. Write independent test cases derived from ACs (not from reading Dev's code)
2. Test edge cases the Dev didn't consider
3. Verify system behaviour from the business perspective, not the implementation perspective
4. Be performed by someone/something that hasn't seen the source code

Root cause: The QA Agent and Dev Agent share the same LLM context — QA has already seen the implementation, so it cannot provide independent validation. This undermines C-02 (Separation of Duties) for testing.

Impact: The "QA Execution Report" currently provides verification theatre — it confirms Dev's tests pass, but adds no independent assurance.

Action: Raise as framework improvement — define UAT as a distinct activity from QA test coordination. Options:
  a) Human UAT tester writes acceptance tests independently
  b) Separate agent session with only story ACs visible (not source code)
  c) QA Agent writes its own test cases from ACs before reviewing Dev's tests

Raised for Sprint 2 retrospective.
